cookingMethod: Use a non-stick pan and spread a thin layer of dosa batter. Use only 1 tsp (5ml) of oil for greasing the pan.
healthTips: Dosa is naturally low in oil. Use a good non-stick pan to reduce oil usage further. Serve with sambar and coconut chutney for a balanced meal.

cookingMethod: Steam the idli batter in idli molds for 10-12 minutes. No oil required.
healthTips: Idli is a perfect zero-oil breakfast option. Rich in protein and easily digestible. Pair with sambar or chutney.

cookingMethod: Pressure cook dal. For tadka, heat 2 tsp (10ml) of ghee or oil, add cumin seeds, onions, and tomatoes. Pour over cooked dal.
healthTips: Use ghee instead of oil for better taste with the same quantity. Dal is protein-rich and the tadka needs minimal oil.

cookingMethod: Use 1 tbsp (15ml) oil to sauté onions, add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, and spices. Add vegetables and cook with little water.
healthTips: Steam or microwave vegetables first to reduce cooking time and oil absorption. Use a pressure cooker to minimize oil usage.

cookingMethod: Knead dough, roll into circles, and cook on a hot tawa. Apply minimal ghee (1 tsp/5ml) after cooking if desired.
healthTips: Chapati requires no oil during cooking. Apply ghee sparingly only for taste. Use whole wheat flour for added fiber.

cookingMethod: Blanch spinach and blend. Use 1 tbsp (15ml) oil to sauté onions, add tomatoes and spices. Mix in spinach puree and paneer cubes.
healthTips: Bake or air-fry paneer instead of deep frying. Use low-fat paneer to reduce overall fat content.

cookingMethod: Heat 2 tsp (10ml) ghee, add cumin seeds. Add washed rice, dal, vegetables, and pressure cook with water and spices.
healthTips: Khichdi is a comfort food that needs minimal oil. Rich in protein and easy to digest. Perfect for a light, healthy meal.

cookingMethod: Dry roast rava. Heat 2 tsp (10ml) oil, add mustard seeds, curry leaves, vegetables. Add water and roasted rava, cook until done.
healthTips: Upma is naturally low in oil. Add more vegetables to increase nutrition and reduce the proportion of semolina.

cookingMethod: Rinse poha and drain. Heat 2 tsp (10ml) oil, add mustard seeds, curry leaves, onions, potato. Mix in poha and spices.
healthTips: Poha is light and requires minimal oil. Add peanuts for protein and crunch. A perfect low-oil breakfast option.

cookingMethod: Pressure cook chickpeas with tea bag. Heat 1 tbsp (15ml) oil, sauté onions, add tomatoes, spices, and cooked chickpeas.
healthTips: Chickpeas are protein-rich and filling. Minimize oil by using a good non-stick pan for sautéing. Serve with brown rice or whole wheat kulcha.
